div.p: Last Week your agreeable Favours of 2d. Current came to hand, which ought to have been immediately acknowledged, had not Business prevented.

Not chusing to destroy any of your Letters, I presume to return inclosed that for
Professor Zimmerman .

Be pleased to give yourself no further uneasyness about Mr. Low's M.S.
having been served with a return some time ago from Mr. Gough, corresponding with a Note I accidentaly met with amongst some of my loose Papers: I am now certain that
the M.S. Journal of his Voyage thro' Orkney & Zetland
was returned to him several years ago & have accordingly refresht his Memory by Letter on that subject: probably the distress with Rheumatisms &c. that he has been so long tormented with may have shortened his Memory &c. being fully persuaded, this must be by him or in the Hands of some of his Friends in Orkney as it was soon after it's arrival from London transmitted by me to him, with this remark to attentively read it over again & correct as much as possible the Language for the Publick Eye: of this I wrote him several weeks ago but have had no Answer, nor heard from him since he wrote me the beginning of the Year, when he was in very pityable Situation, since from the late agreable weather we have been favour'd with, he has got considerably relieved, of this I am assured by friends who saw him not long since.

His silence deserves Censure, especialy to you, but I can & do forgive him, having no Inclination to differ with any Person, unless I be maltreated, — then I've no further connection, when all correspondence is at an End. ––––– But from my Knowledge of Mr. Low, I think, I may assure you, that provided a Publication takes place, any reasonable request (as you modestly suggest to me) will be granted: this I'm under necessity to see performed to both your mutual satisfactions, since the first Correspondence commenced.
Pray can you inform me to what extent of Nos. is Mr. Cordiner to continue his "Picturesque Views &c. in Scotland"?

I am sorry to hear that Mr. Gough has had the misfortune any how to be roughly treated ; the particulars are unknown to me & it grieves me much that any such difference has happened: for my own part I freely confess since the year 1772, this most cordial correspondent friendly Intimacy has to this moment & hope shall in future subsist as long as we live: — that such be the same between us shall ever be the study of

closer.salute:
Dear Sir
Your most obedt. Servt.
